headline: Rafael Nadal Wins U.S. Open
summary: The 24-year-old Spaniard won his first U.S. Open title Monday evening after a nearly two-hour rain delay, 6-4, 5-7, 6-4, 6-2 over Novak Djokovic, the Serb who toppled Roger Federer in the semifinals.

headline: Oddly Cobbled Pipe Eyed in Gas Blast
summary: Investigators probing the huge explosion in San Bruno, Calif., found an unusually-built section of pipe in the ashen ruins, focusing attention on the pipeline operator's inspections.

summary: Japan frees 14 crew members of a Chinese fishing ship, Afghanistan prepares for national elections, Thai senators fight in front of the parliament to promote Thai boxing, and more.

headline: Toyota to Launch 6 New Hybrids by 2012
summary: Toyota will introduce six new hybrid, gasoline-electric vehicles by 2012 on a global basis, the auto maker's chief engineer said.

headline: VA Makes Changes in Life-Insurance Accounts
summary: The Department of Veterans Affairs will make changes in the military's life-insurance program, an issue thrust into the spotlight when the mother of a solider killed in Afghanistan said she felt misled about the accounts.

headline: White House Mulls Interim Role for Warren at Consumer Agency
summary: The White House is considering appointing Harvard Law School Professor Elizabeth Warren to an interim role to help set up a new Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection.

summary: Citigroup defended its settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission over its disclosure of subprime mortgage exposure, setting the stage for a federal judge to decide whether to approve the deal.

headline: Blockbuster Says CFO Resigned Over Weekend
summary: Troubled video-rental chain Blockbuster Inc. said in a Monday filing that Thomas Casey had resigned as executive vice president and chief financial officer, effective Sept. 11.

headline: DvF: Boldface Forward
summary: A fuchsia dress in silk jersey with a hood and a saturated mustard top with a purple silk skirt in Diane von Furstenberg's spring collection drove home the message: Do not fear color, women!

headline: Regulator Rebuffs Shallow-Water Drillers Over Permits
summary: The government's top offshore drilling regulator, responding to pressure from the oil and gas industry, said Monday his agency wouldn't approve new shallow-water drilling permits until companies proved compliance with new safety requirements.

headline: Duties Proposed on China's Seamless Pipe
summary: The Commerce Department proposed antidumping and countervailing duties against seamless pipe imports from China, amid growing signs of tension in the U.S.-China trade relationship.

headline: New Medicare Chief Pledges to Cut Costs
summary: A contentious Obama administration appointee who runs Medicare and Medicaid offered his first road map for the programs, pledging to lower medical costs without harming patients.

summary: Corporate Watch

summary: Bill Telepan's eponymous restaurant, which offers American fare and an eclectic wine list, is a mainstay for Upper West Side residents and Lincoln Center patrons.

summary: The state's addiction to gambling revenue.

headline: Magna to Lose Co-CEO
summary: Magna International said Siegfried Wolf is stepping down as co-chief executive of the Canadian auto-parts maker to take a position in the Russian auto industry.

summary: Don't buy the line that bank stocks are rallying because the weekend's "Basel III" pact on stricter capital rules brought "clarity" to the regulatory outlook.

headline: Report Examines Lending in Housing Boom
summary: A new report by the regulator of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac shows that mortgage securities packaged by Wall Street firms and mortgage banks have had substantially worse outcomes than securities backed by the two mortgage titans.

headline: False-Ad Claim Thrown Out in eBay-Tiffany  Case
summary: The lone remaining claim was thrown out Monday in a long-running dispute between jeweler Tiffany and online auctioneer eBay over the sale of counterfeit Tiffany items on eBay's website.

headline: Program Trading
summary: Program trading in the week ended Sept. 3 amounted to 33.4% of New York Stock Exchange average daily volume of 2.22 billion shares, or 741.0 million program shares traded per day.

headline: Clinton Pushes on Core Mideast Issues
summary: Secretary of State Hillary Clinton pledged to push Israelis and Palestinians to move quickly toward resolving the core issues required to establish an independent Palestinian state, suggesting the status of a West Bank building freeze shouldn't be a deal-breaker.

headline: U.S. Foodservice to Pay Fine
summary: A U.S. food distribution company agreed to pay $30 million to settle civil fraud charges that it falsely inflated the price it charged the U.S. government for food products over a five-year period, prosecutors said Monday.

headline: Bank Shares Rally in Europe
summary: European stocks rose, with banks leading the advance as investors welcomed new, tougher rules on capital adequacy that weren't as harsh as had been feared. Asian stocks also advanced.

headline: Dow Boosted by Banks
summary: Stocks and the euro rose after regulators decided on a long phase-in period for tighter requirements on bank-capital ratios.

headline: Basel Opts for Paradise Postponed
summary: In response to the greatest financial crisis in 70 years, the world has finally agreed to tough new rules to make the banking system safe—in eight years, a mere 11 years after the crisis first started.

headline: Notable & Quotable: Camille Paglia on Lady Gaga
summary: The American cultural critic writes about the Internet generation's biggest star in the Sunday Times Magazine.

headline: Redemption Notices
summary: The following is a list of securities called for partial or complete redemption in the week ended Saturday. The notices are taken from advertisements appearing in editions of The Wall Street Journal and aren't meant to be definitive.

headline: A Makeover at the Vatican
summary: After an $11.5 million renovation aimed at upgrading security and climate controls, the Vatican's Apostolic LIbrary is ready to reopen to researchers.

headline: Crude Hits One-Month High
summary: Crude futures ended at a one-month high Monday, as the latest evidence of strong economic growth in China boosted the outlook for oil demand.

headline: Churchill Downs Grows Casino Holdings
summary: Churchill Downs Inc. has agreed to acquire Harlow's Casino Resort & Hotel in Mississippi for about $138 million as the horse-racing company continues to expand its business into casinos.

summary: In Monday's pictures, miners strike in Spain, fish fly in China, an Afghan woman makes her way through town and more.

headline: FDA Mulls Removal of Weight-Loss Drug
summary: A federal advisory panel is being asked to help decide whether Abbott Laboratories' weight-loss drug Meridia should stay on the market.

headline: Gold Prices Rise on Lingering Fears
summary: Gold managed to eke out a small gain Monday, evidence not all are convinced everything is going all right with the world's economy.

headline: Cement From BP Well to Be Tested
summary: Federal prosecutors plan to test the cement used in the blown-out BP in the Gulf of Mexico, a step that will put under scrutiny BP's conclusion that the spill in U.S. history started with faulty cement.

headline: Chinese Firms Line Up Hong Kong IPOs
summary: China's Winsway Coking Coal began pre-marketing a $1 billion IPO in Hong Kong, while two other mainland firms launched investor presentations for IPOs aiming to raise up to US$845 million combined.

headline: Sanofi Could Refinance Loan
summary: French drugmaker Sanofi-Aventis SA is likely to refinance part of an approximate $10 billion loan in the bond market it lined up for its bid to buy Genzyme, people familiar with the situation said.

headline: Bank Shares Rally in Europe
summary: European stock markets rallied, with banks leading the way higher as investors reacted positively to new global guidelines for financial institutions.

headline: EU Raises 2010 Growth Forecasts

headline: Apollo to Merge Momentive Performance, Hexion
summary: Private-equity giant Apollo Management LP is merging chemical companies Momentive Performance Materials Holdings Inc. and Hexion LLC, with Apollo co-founder Josh Harris saying the time is right in making the combined entity "a global player in the specialty materials space."

headline: How to Buy Gold Coins and Bars
summary: Buying the purest form of gold may not always be your best bet because it can be hard to sell in time of need, says Shefali Anand, India personal finance writer.

headline: Turks Pass Constitutional Changes
summary: Turks approved sweeping changes to their military-era constitution Sunday -- a referendum hailed by the government as a leap toward full democracy in line with its troubled bid to join the European Union.

headline: Rio Tinto Boosts Ivanhoe Mines Stake
summary: Anglo-Australian miner Rio Tinto it increased its stake in Ivanhoe Mines, a Vancouver-based miner developing one of the world's largest new gold-copper mines in Mongolia.

headline: MF Global Loses Brokers in Singapore
summary: MF Global's oil and fuel brokering business has been hit by a wave of defections in Singapore, with at least 10 brokers departing.

headline: Italian Strikers Have New Goal
summary: Football fans in Italy are about to see even fewer goals than usual.

headline: Soggy Day at the Tennis Courts
summary: Rain postponed the title match between Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic Sunday, the third consecutive year the U.S. Open won't finish on schedule. The title match is schedule to begin at 4 p.m. Monday.

headline: Japanese Bonds Slide on Election Speculation
summary: Japanese government bonds fell because of speculation that Ichiro Ozawa, who has promised heavy spending to boost the economy, may beat Prime Minister Naoto Kan in Tuesday's race to lead the ruling Democratic Party of Japan.

summary: In "On Mutual Funds, Cheaper is Better" (op-ed, Aug 27) John C. Bogle states that "The huge economies of scale in managing other people's money have largely been arrogated by fund managers to their own benefit rather than to the benefit of fund shareholders."

summary: New exhibits that showcase industrial design remind us that objects that work properly, stand the test of time, and have an agreeable shape are simply not the norm in this country.

headline: Grant's Daughter Missed All the Fun

headline: AOL to Offer Bigger, Fancier Ads

summary: The Philippine government raised $1 billion through the sale of its first ever peso-denominated global bond, a move designed to cut its foreign-exchange risk.

summary: The GOP's hopes to retake control of the House this year rest in part on winning support from some unlikely places, such as heavily Democratic New York State.

summary: Lower Manhattan was a terror target in 1920, too.

headline: The Wind Gap

headline: Water Surge
summary: Hydropower, once shunned because of environmental concerns, is making a comeback. But not in the form of new dams. Instead, engineers and entrepreneurs argue for drawing power from ocean waves, free-flowing rivers, irrigation ditches—and existing dams that aren't currently used for electricity.

headline: Criticism of U.K.'s NHS is Mistaken
